item.title: @TonyZador @Mark_Solms @pennybun01 @GaryMarcus @WiringTheBrain @anne_churchland @Nancy_Kanwisher @neurograce no question that finely layered cortex of mammals is beautiful innovation. I just don't like to discount enormous complexity/"power" of vertebrate brains. Doing that we realize that there's so much to understand about the differences. I'm strongly non corticocentric in that sense

item.title: This project started as a conversation between @abigails_greene , @coreyhorien, and I about “brain state.” We each use this term in descriptions of our research ranging from whole-brain fMRI in patient populations (Abby, Corey) to cell- and circuit-level recordings in mice (me).
item.description: This project started as a conversation between @abigails_greene , @coreyhorien, and I about “brain state.” We each use this term in descriptions of our research ranging from whole-brain fMRI in patient populations (Abby, Corey) to cell- and circuit-level recordings in mice (me).
item.content:encoded: This project started as a conversation between @abigails_greene , @coreyhorien, and I about “brain state.” We each use this term in descriptions of our research ranging from whole-brain fMRI in patient populations (Abby, Corey) to cell- and circuit-level recordings in mice (me).

item.title: We wondered if there was anything in common between what each of us was referring to as a “brain state.” And does it actually matter?
item.description: We wondered if there was anything in common between what each of us was referring to as a “brain state.” And does it actually matter?
item.content:encoded: We wondered if there was anything in common between what each of us was referring to as a “brain state.” And does it actually matter?

item.title: What emerged was a roadmap for collaboration that we intend to follow in our future work and a guide for the principled use of “brain state” in both the planning and interpretation of experiments.
item.description: What emerged was a roadmap for collaboration that we intend to follow in our future work and a guide for the principled use of “brain state” in both the planning and interpretation of experiments.
item.content:encoded: What emerged was a roadmap for collaboration that we intend to follow in our future work and a guide for the principled use of “brain state” in both the planning and interpretation of experiments.

item.title: This was a challenging project and we owe a debt of gratitude to our coauthors, @DScheinost @constable_todd, my advisors (formal and informal) @MCrair @mjhigley and @jess_cardin, and the members of their labs, for many helpful and inspiring conversations.
item.description: This was a challenging project and we owe a debt of gratitude to our coauthors, @DScheinost @constable_todd, my advisors (formal and informal) @MCrair @mjhigley and @jess_cardin, and the members of their labs, for many helpful and inspiring conversations.
item.content:encoded: This was a challenging project and we owe a debt of gratitude to our coauthors, @DScheinost @constable_todd, my advisors (formal and informal) @MCrair @mjhigley and @jess_cardin, and the members of their labs, for many helpful and inspiring conversations.

item.title: We re-wrote this paper twice in response to formative feedback from our advisors and (anonymous) peer reviewers. So, thank you to those contributors, and particularly to our editor at @TrendsNeuro @MoranFurman, for getting us over the finish line!
